intro: Lepidaploa coulonioides, commonly known as the mountain dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes in South America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble dandelions. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold, mountainous environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and bloom in late summer. Lepidaploa coulonioides is often found in alpine meadows and is a symbol of resilience in harsh climates.
